intro: Wyomingia tweedyana, commonly known as the Wyoming milkvetch, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Fabaceae family, which includes legumes, and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, pea-like flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments. It plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing forage for wildlife. Wyomingia tweedyana is also of interest to botanists due to its unique adaptations to its harsh habitat.
